Imagine you are playing the game as Elizabeth.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Brenda, Elizabeth, Kimberly, Nicole, Richard, Scott, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Elizabeth's) goal: Deceive others, avoid detection, and eliminate villagers.

prompt.content:
Imagine you are playing the game as Brenda.

Here is the description of the game: This game is called Werewolves (also known as Mafia), which is a social deduction game.  GAME STRUCTURE: This game contains six players: two villagers, two werewolves, one seer, and one witch. Each cycle consists of Night phases followed by Day phases. WIN CONDITIONS: Villagers win by eliminating all Werewolves. Werewolves win when they equal or outnumber the Villagers. NIGHT PHASES: (1) Werewolves wake and privately choose one Villager to kill using 'kill NAME'. (2) The Seer wakes and inspects one player using 'inspect NAME' to learn if they are a Werewolf or Villager. (3) The Witch wakes and may use their one-time save potion with 'save NAME' (if someone died tonight) or their one-time poison potion with 'poison NAME' to kill someone. DAY PHASES: (1) Dawn: All players learn who died during the night (if any). (2) Discussion: All living players go *one* round of public discussion to discuss and debate who might be a Werewolf. Use 'speak' to share your thoughts and suspicions. (3) Voting: Each player votes to eliminate one suspected Werewolf using 'vote NAME'. The player with the most votes is executed. (4) Twilight: The execution result is announced and night returns. COMMUNICATION RULES: All day discussions are public. Dead players cannot speak or act. If 'action' is available, use commands like 'kill NAME', 'inspect NAME', 'save NAME', 'poison NAME', or 'vote NAME'. Note: Player actions in the nights are not seen by players of other roles (e.g. only wolves can see other wolves' actions). Day discussion is public. Voting requires an 'action' beginning with 'vote'.

The players in this game are: Brenda, Elizabeth, Kimberly, Nicole, Richard, Scott, and during the day, they speak in the same order as they are listed.

Your (Brenda's) goal: Act openly and collaboratively to identify werewolves.

{secret}

Here is the context of the interaction:


Conversation Starts:

Turn #0: [Game] State: Night_werewolf. The game begins!

Turn #1: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #2: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #3: [Game] An attack was prevented!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #4: Brenda: said: "I'm glad the attack was prevented—thank you, Witch! This means someone is still alive who might be crucial. Let’s think: Who could have been targeted? Since the Witch saved someone, it’s likely they were trying to protect an innocent. I’m suspicious of anyone who seemed too quiet or tried to redirect attention. Let’s hear everyone’s thoughts—Elizabeth, you’re next. What did you notice last night?"

Turn #5: Elizabeth: said: "I didn't notice anything unusual last night—Nicole was the one who was targeted, and I'm not sure why that would be suspicious. I trust the Witch's judgment to protect the innocent. I think we should focus on who might have been trying to manipulate the discussion. Maybe someone is trying to shift blame or create false leads. But I don't have any concrete evidence against anyone."

Turn #6: Kimberly: said: "I appreciate the Witch’s intervention—it’s a relief we lost no one. But I’m curious: why did Elizabeth say Nicole was targeted? No one died, so the Witch must have saved someone before the attack took effect. That means the Werewolves targeted someone, and the Witch acted in time. Nicole wasn’t mentioned as the target before—so why bring her up now? That feels like an attempt to mislead us. I think we should be wary of whoever’s trying to steer suspicion toward someone who wasn’t even in danger."

Turn #7: Nicole: said: "I'm not surprised that Elizabeth mentioned Nicole—she was the one who was targeted last night, and I was also the one who responded to that. But let's be clear: the Witch saved someone, and that means the attack was prevented. Elizabeth's timing in bringing up Nicole feels a bit off, especially since she didn't know what the Witch saved. I think we should focus on who might have been trying to manipulate the narrative. I personally don't see any reason to suspect anyone, but I remain cautious—because trust is hard to earn in this game."

Turn #8: Richard: said: "I agree with Kimberly—Elizabeth’s sudden mention of Nicole feels suspicious. She didn’t know who the Witch saved, yet she immediately named Nicole as the target. That’s not something a regular villager would know unless they were involved in the Night phase—maybe even a Werewolf trying to plant doubt. I think Elizabeth is either lying or trying to manipulate the narrative. We should vote her out if no one else has a stronger claim."

Turn #9: Scott: said: "I agree with Kimberly and Richard—Elizabeth’s immediate claim that Nicole was targeted is highly suspicious. She couldn’t possibly know who the Witch saved unless she was involved in the Night phase. That’s not something a villager or seer would know without acting—and she didn’t claim to be the seer. This feels like an attempt to misdirect us. I’m concerned Elizabeth might be a Werewolf trying to frame Nicole and create chaos. We should take this seriously and vote her out today."
[Game] Entering state: Day_vote

Turn #10: Brenda: [action] vote Elizabeth
Elizabeth: [action] vote Scott
Kimberly: [action] vote Elizabeth
Nicole: [action] vote Scott
Richard: [action] vote Elizabeth
Scott: [action] vote Elizabeth
[Game] Elizabeth was voted out!
[Game] Entering state: Night_werewolf

Turn #11: [Game] Entering state: Night_seer

Turn #12: [Game] Entering state: Night_witch

Turn #13: [Game] Scott was killed by werewolves!
[Game] Entering state: Day_discussion

Turn #14: Brenda: said: "Scott was killed last night—that’s a major loss. The Werewolves are targeting key players, and now we’re down to four: me, Kimberly, Nicole, and Richard. Elizabeth was eliminated because she wrongly claimed to know who the Witch saved, which made her look suspicious—but now that Scott is dead, we need to reevaluate. Who benefits from Scott’s death? He was vocal and aligned with Kimberly and Richard in accusing Elizabeth. That makes me wonder: if Scott, Kimberly, and Richard were all on the same side, maybe they’re working together to eliminate threats. I’m not accusing anyone yet, but we need to be careful. Kimberly and Richard: why did you both support Scott’s elimination of Elizabeth? Was that a coincidence, or are you coordinating? Nicole, what do you think about the pattern here?"

Turn #15: Kimberly: said: "Scott’s death is a blow, but it also reveals something important—Elizabeth was wrongfully accused because she mentioned Nicole, and now Scott, who supported that accusation, is dead. That’s too convenient. If Kimberly and Richard both voted to eliminate Elizabeth—and now Scott is gone—this looks like a coordinated effort to remove dissent. I’m not saying Richard or Kimberly are werewolves, but their alignment with Scott and the timing of his death raises red flags. Nicole and I are the only ones left who didn’t vote to eliminate Elizabeth. That doesn’t make us guilty—it makes us the last unaligned players. We need to stick together and look for the real threat: someone who knew Scott was a target before he died. And no one else knew that but the Werewolves."

Turn #16: Nicole: said: "I appreciate the discussion, but let me clarify something: I didn’t target Elizabeth in the night—she was the one who initiated the attack on me. I reacted in self-defense. As for Scott’s death, I have no knowledge of any prior targeting. My actions were purely based on survival. I remain neutral and open to the group’s judgment, but I must emphasize: I have no motive to harm anyone. If suspicion falls on me, it’s because of the narrative being shaped by others. I trust the process, but I will stay vigilant."

Turn #17: Richard: said: "Scott’s death confirms we’re up against skilled Werewolves—someone knew exactly who to target after Elizabeth was eliminated. Kimberly and I voted against Elizabeth because her claim about Nicole was suspicious, but Scott’s death now suggests the Werewolves are targeting those who expose inconsistencies. I’m not coordinating with Kimberly—we both saw Elizabeth’s behavior as a red flag independently. Nicole, you’re the only one who hasn’t taken a clear stance. If you’re innocent, now is the time to help us identify the real threat before it strikes again."
